text: LIZ JOHNSON: Hi, everyone.
I'm Liz Johnson.

I'm a research
associate here at HBS.

And I'm sure you've seen
me running around all day.

I'm very excited
to share with you

some exploratory
early stage findings
on sexual harassment at work.

So the data I'll be talking
with you today about

is from the Life and
Leadership After HBS

Survey, which is a
longitudinal survey sent
to all MBA graduates.

And in this second
wave of the survey,

we sent it out to
approximately 33,000 alarms.

And we heard back
from about 5,600.

And these results,
we're just looking

at men and women who are working
full-time in an organization.

So in the second wave of the
Life and Leadership Survey,

we were really interested
in understanding

what predicts
women's experiences

of sexual harassment as well as
men's anxieties and behaviors
in reaction to MeToo.

So Tori talked a little bit
about that in her flash talk

and how MeToo has shaped men's
anxieties about mentoring women
at work.

And we're hoping to add
some complementary findings

on contextual
organizational factors that

may also influence
men's anxieties
and reaction to MeToo.

So we decided to look at two
potential structural predictors
for experiences and reactions.

We looked at the percent
of senior women leaders
and masculinity contests.

So percent of
senior women leaders

we measured by
asking participants,

how many of your senior
leaders are women?

And for masculinity
contests, which

are the extent to which
an organization endorses

masculine norms, we
asked participants

to respond to the six bulleted
items which are fulfilling
three masculine contest norms.

And they rated how
truthful these norms
were for their organization.

And we then averaged their
responses to these six items

to create a masculinity
contest scale.

So for our outcomes, we
looked at women's experiences.

And we asked women
whether or not

they had experienced any
of these nine behaviors

that you're seeing
on the screen.

I don't have time
to go through all

of the percentages
for each behavior,

but the most common
was the first row--

makes sexually
suggestive remarks.

And 45% of women had
experienced this at work.

We then conducted a factor
analysis on these nine items

and found that there were
three subscales, what we're

going to call verbal harassment,
physical harassment, and gender
harassment.

So then we looked to see
if masculinity contests

and percent of senior women
predicted these three outcomes.

And so we did find
that there was

a significant
positive relationship

between masculinity contests
and verbal sexual harassment
and gender harassment.

So as masculine norms are
increasing in the workplace,

verbal and gender harassment
are also increasing.

And we found a significant
negative relationship

between the percent of senior
women and all three outcomes.

So as your percent
of senior women

is rising in the workplace,
the instances of harassment
are going down.

So then we looked at men's
reactions to the MeToo climate.

And we wanted to know
about men's anxieties

about harassment and being
accused of harassment as well

as these withdrawal
or avoidance behaviors
in interactions with women.

So again, we looked at
masculinity contests
and the percent of senior women.

And we found only one
significant relationship.

And that was that masculinity
contests significantly

positively predicted these
avoidance or withdrawal
behaviors of women at work.

So in conclusion, our
preliminary results

are showing some
interesting relationships

between having more women
in senior positions being

associated with less
sexual harassment.

A work environment with
more masculine norms

is predicting some forms
of sexual harassment.

And as Tori has
talked about, there

seems to be this general
cultural backlash occurring

against MeToo in terms
of these withdrawals

of social resources, both
mentoring and meeting
with women.
And so thank you.

And thank you to Rob and
Peter, Laurie, and Colleen
who all were on this project.
